answers.text:
plotdata <- as.matrix(data)

barplot(plotdata, beside = FALSE,col = c("red4","orange3","yellow3","green3"),
        xlab = "", ylab = "Population", ylim=c(0,28000))

legend("top",ncol=4, legend =c("Low", "Medium", "High", "Very High"), fill = c("red4","orange3","yellow3","green3"), title = "Income")

plotdata <- matrix(data$Population, ncol=2, byrow=FALSE, dimnames = list(c("Low", "Medium", "High", "Very High"),c("City A", "City B")))

barplot(plotdata, beside = FALSE, col = c("red4","orange3","yellow3","green3"),
        xlab = "", ylab = "Population", ylim=c(0,28000))            
      
legend("top",ncol=4, legend =c("Low", "Medium", "High", "Very High"), fill = c("red4","orange3","yellow3","green3"), title = "Income")

tipsAndFeedback.tip:
If your data is already summarized and in a "wide" format where each row represents a complete summary, you typically do not need to use table(). 
In this case, you can directly use the summarized data in form of a matrix to create your barplot.

answers.text:
plotdata <- table(data$City, data$Income_Level)

barplot(plotdata, beside = FALSE, col = c("red4","orange3","yellow3","green3"),
        xlab = "", ylab = "Population", ylim=c(0,28000))

legend("top",ncol=4, legend =c("Low", "Medium", "High", "Very High"), fill = c("red4","orange3","yellow3","green3"), title = "Income")

params.question:
The following data is given:

data <- data.frame(
  City = rep(c("City A", "City B"), each = 4),
  Income_Level = c("Low", "Medium", "High", "Very High", "Low", "Medium", "High", "Very High"),
  Population = c(5000, 8000, 6000, 4000, 9000, 10000, 3000, 500)
)

You should now display the population size for each city comparably, i.e. side by side.  At the same time, you should also show what proportion of the total population is in the high, low, etc. salary class.

Which code would lead to the desired result?

answers.text:
barplot(table(data$City, data$School_Type), beside = F, 
        main = "Distribution of School Types by City",
        xlab = "City", col=c("red4","orange3","yellow2"))
legend("topleft", legend = unique(data$School_Type),title = "School Type", fill=c("red4","orange3","yellow2"), bty="n")

barplot(table(data$School_Type, data$City), beside = F, 
        main = "Distribution of School Types by City",
        xlab = "City", col=c("red4","orange3","yellow2"))
legend("topleft", legend = unique(data$School_Type),title = "School Type", fill=c("red4","orange3","yellow2"), bty="n")

params.question:
Given the following data:

data <- data.frame(
  City = c("City A", "City A", "City A", "City A", "City A", 
           "City B","City B", "City B", "City B", "City B", "City B", "City B"),
  School_Type = c("Elementary", "Elementary", "Secondary",  "Gymnasium","Secondary", 
                  "Gymnasium","Elementary", "Elementary","Elementary", "Secondary", "Secondary","Gymnasium"),
  School_Name = c("School 1", "School 2", "School 3", "School 4", "School 5", "School 6",
                  "School 7", "School 8", "School 9", "School 10", "School 11", "School 12")
)

You should now display the number of school buildings per school type for each city in the form of a barplot, with one bar per city

Which code would lead to the desired result?
